content:
Which of the following is an essential amino acid in humans?
A Tyrosine
B Glutamine
C Glutamate
D Phenylalanine
E Lysine
The term “ketogenic” describes an amino acid that:
A is a precursor for glucose synthesis.
B forms oxaloacetate during catabolism.
C cannot be converted to ketone bodies.
D degrades to give a-ketoglutarate.
E is catabolised to yield acetyl CoA or acetoacetyl CoA.
Which of the following statements regarding glutamate dehydrogenase is INCORRECT?
A It can use either NAD+ or NADP+ as a coenzyme.
B It catalyses an essentially reversible reaction.
C When catalysing the conversion of glutamate to its carbon skeleton, the reaction involves deamination.
D It is not subject to allosteric regulation.
E It is located in the mitochondria.
How is glutamate useful in amino acid synthesis reactions?
A It activates glutaminase to release free glutamine.
B It can be reduced and cyclised to form glycine.
C It acts as an amino group donor for synthesis of nonessential amino acids.
D It is the main precursor of tyrosine synthesis.
E It is the main methyl group donor for essential amino acids.
Which of the following statements is correct?
A In humans, nonessential amino acids are exclusively synthesised from essential amino acids.
B Humans can attain nonessential amino acids from a protein-rich diet.
C Alanine is a common methyl group donor in human essential amino acid synthesis.
D In humans, aspartate is formed from pyruvate and is therefore a nonessential amino acid.
E All nonessential amino acids are catabolised to form acetoacetate.
Which of the following statements regarding tyrosine in humans is correct?
A Tyrosine is an essential amino acid as it cannot be synthesised.
B Catecholamines are formed following deamination of tyrosine.
C Tyrosine is the main precursor of carnitine in the liver.
D Tyrosine is commonly converted directly to serotonin or melatonin.
E Tyrosine is an important precursor of thyroxine in the thyroid gland.
Which of the following is an important role of ornithine in humans?
A It is one of the 20 common amino acids in all of our proteins.
B It is a key intermediate in the TCA cycle, combining with acetyl CoA to form citrate.
C It is an intermediate in the urea cycle in the kidney.
D It is one of two ways that NH3 groups can travel safely in blood.
E It is required for the cyclisation of proline.
Which of the following statements regarding the urea cycle in humans is INCORRECT?
A It aids in the excretion of nitrogen from the body.
B It is linked to the TCA cycle through fumarate.
C It occurs mainly in the liver and kidney.
D It is reduced when the activity of carbamoyl phosphate synthase I is activated.
E All reactions occur in the cytosol.
Which of the following best describes the energy needs of the urea cycle?
A 6 ATP equivalents: 4 as ATP → ADP and 2 as GTP → GDP.
B 4 ATP equivalents: 2 as ATP → ADP and 1 as ATP → AMP.
C 2 ATP equivalents: 2 as ATP → ADP, plus 2 NADH → NAD+.
D 3 ATP equivalents: 2 as ATP → ADP and 1 as ATP → AMP.
E The urea cycle does not require energy input as it is a catabolic cycle breaking down ammonia.
The primary function of the urea cycle is to:
A produce ATP.
B synthesise amino acids.
C detoxify ammonia.
D generate NADH.
E produce urine.
Which amino acid is involved in the transport of nitrogen from peripheral tissues to the liver?
A Methionine
B Glutamine
C Leucine
D Valine
E Isoleucine
What is a primary role of glutamate dehydrogenase in amino acid catabolism?
A Conversion of glutamate to alpha-ketoglutarate
B Synthesis of glutamine from glutamate
C Oxidation of amino acids for energy
D Formation of urea from ammonia
E Conversion of ammonia to urea

multiple_choice_questions.question: Which of the following is an essential amino acid in humans?
The term “ketogenic” describes an amino acid that:

options.A: is a precursor for glucose synthesis.
options.C: cannot be converted to ketone bodies.
options.E: is catabolised to yield acetyl CoA or acetoacetyl CoA.

multiple_choice_questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding glutamate dehydrogenase is INCORRECT?

options.A: It can use either NAD+ or NADP+ as a coenzyme.
options.B: It catalyses an essentially reversible reaction.
options.C: When catalysing the conversion of glutamate to its carbon skeleton, the reaction involves deamination.
options.D: It is not subject to allosteric regulation.
options.E: It is located in the mitochondria.

multiple_choice_questions.question: How is glutamate useful in amino acid synthesis reactions?

options.A: It activates glutaminase to release free glutamine.
options.B: It can be reduced and cyclised to form glycine.
options.C: It acts as an amino group donor for synthesis of nonessential amino acids.
options.D: It is the main precursor of tyrosine synthesis.
options.E: It is the main methyl group donor for essential amino acids.

multiple_choice_questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: In humans, nonessential amino acids are exclusively synthesised from essential amino acids.
options.B: Humans can attain nonessential amino acids from a protein-rich diet.
options.C: Alanine is a common methyl group donor in human essential amino acid synthesis.
options.D: In humans, aspartate is formed from pyruvate and is therefore a nonessential amino acid.
options.E: All nonessential amino acids are catabolised to form acetoacetate.

multiple_choice_questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding tyrosine in humans is correct?

options.A: Tyrosine is an essential amino acid as it cannot be synthesised.
options.B: Catecholamines are formed following deamination of tyrosine.
options.C: Tyrosine is the main precursor of carnitine in the liver.
options.D: Tyrosine is commonly converted directly to serotonin or melatonin.
options.E: Tyrosine is an important precursor of thyroxine in the thyroid gland.

multiple_choice_questions.question: Which of the following is an important role of ornithine in humans?

options.A: It is one of the 20 common amino acids in all of our proteins.
options.B: It is a key intermediate in the TCA cycle, combining with acetyl CoA to form citrate.
options.C: It is an intermediate in the urea cycle in the kidney.
options.D: It is one of two ways that NH3 groups can travel safely in blood.
options.E: It is required for the cyclisation of proline.

multiple_choice_questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the urea cycle in humans is INCORRECT?

options.A: It aids in the excretion of nitrogen from the body.
options.B: It is linked to the TCA cycle through fumarate.
options.C: It occurs mainly in the liver and kidney.
options.D: It is reduced when the activity of carbamoyl phosphate synthase I is activated.
options.E: All reactions occur in the cytosol.

multiple_choice_questions.question: Which of the following best describes the energy needs of the urea cycle?

options.A: 6 ATP equivalents: 4 as ATP → ADP and 2 as GTP → GDP.
options.B: 4 ATP equivalents: 2 as ATP → ADP and 1 as ATP → AMP.
options.C: 2 ATP equivalents: 2 as ATP → ADP, plus 2 NADH → NAD+.
options.D: 3 ATP equivalents: 2 as ATP → ADP and 1 as ATP → AMP.
options.E: The urea cycle does not require energy input as it is a catabolic cycle breaking down ammonia.

multiple_choice_questions.question: The primary function of the urea cycle is to:
Which amino acid is involved in the transport of nitrogen from peripheral tissues to the liver?
What is a primary role of glutamate dehydrogenase in amino acid catabolism?

options.C: Oxidation of amino acids for energy
